Award.AwardTitle: COMPLEXITY-BUILDING ANNULATION REACTIONS WITH STRAINED RING BUILDING BLOCKS
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Jeffrey Johnson of the Department of Chemistry at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill to develop new catalytic, enantioselective methods for the construction of heterocycles using readily accessible strained building blocks. Prior NSF-funded research has revealed a unique mechanism for tetrahydrofuran-forming annulation reactions between donor-acceptor cyclopropanes and aldehydes. From this point, other useful heterocycle constructions, including asymmetric variants, have been achieved. The mechanistic understanding gained to date is expected to drive the discovery of new reactions that allow simple access to structures not easily reached using existing methods. Examining new chemistry of donor-acceptor cyclopropanes and exploring the reactivity of heretofore unexplored donor-acceptor strained systems is expected to provide a diverse set of reaction products. A complete exploration of the useful yet underutilized "carbon as a nucleofuge" paradigm will lead to useful reaction patterns. Experimentation in these areas will also provide fertile ground for fundamental studies of reaction mechanism in transformations that involve ground state-destabilized building blocks.

The development of a general platform for heterocycle construction using strained ring activation is of fundamental importance to organic and medicinal chemists. The exploration of myriad activation modes for the donor-acceptor substrates is likely to enhance adoption of the methodology in academic and industrial laboratories. Graduate student coworkers will become adept at a broad range of synthetic and analytical techniques that can be applied to a variety of problems. Through the continued inclusion of student researchers via the AVS Project SEED program, ethnic minorities that are historically underrepresented in the sciences will have access to cutting edge, yet tractable science.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project focused on the general question of how to convert simple small molecule building blocks into more complex functionalized structures, in defined three-dimensional relationships, in a straightforward manner using catalyst control.  The work has provided access to heretofore unknown small molecule building blocks that may be useful in a variety of contexts (e.g. drug discovery).  We have successfully used ring strain as a molecular “spring” that can be sprung through the action of an appropriate catalyst, a Lewis acid. By exploiting a common mechanistic framework, a range of products were created with the donor-acceptor cyclopropane building blocks.  This project has also illustrated the value of hypothesis-driven research insofar as mechanistic studies revealed shortcomings of the strain-release paradigm that led us to explore new directions in the research.  This course change led to the opportunity to explore ring strain/strain release in the context of aromatic systems and the unique finding that certain transformations of cyclopropanated benzenes can be dramatically accelerated in water as the reaction medium.  This finding may have significant implications for future reaction designs and we continue to be interested in transformations that convert feedstock chemicals into novel, useful structures in short order.  As indicated in the accompanying figure, a great range of diverse, complex structures was made available in only two steps from benzene.    Our research team that worked this project was diverse, and had many opportunities to engage in outreach at nearby elementary schools.

 


Last Modified: 07/27/2017
Modified by: Jeffrey S Johnson

Image
  • Water accelerated synthesis facilitates the preparation of diverse, functionalized small molecules from feedstock chemicals
    jeffrey johnson

    Jeffrey S Johnson
    Product Diversity from a Common Platform
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This research project focused on the general question of how to convert simple small molecule building blocks into more complex functionalized structures, in defined three-dimensional relationships, in a straightforward manner using catalyst control. The work has provided access to heretofore unknown small molecule building blocks that may be useful in a variety of contexts (e.g. drug discovery). We have successfully used ring strain as a molecular "spring" that can be sprung through the action of an appropriate catalyst, a Lewis acid. By exploiting a common mechanistic framework, a range of products were created with the donor-acceptor cyclopropane building blocks. This project has also illustrated the value of hypothesis-driven research insofar as mechanistic studies revealed shortcomings of the strain-release paradigm that led us to explore new directions in the research. This course change led to the opportunity to explore ring strain/strain release in the context of aromatic systems and the unique finding that certain transformations of cyclopropanated benzenes can be dramatically accelerated in water as the reaction medium. This finding may have significant implications for future reaction designs and we continue to be interested in transformations that convert feedstock chemicals into novel, useful structures in short order. As indicated in the accompanying figure, a great range of diverse, complex structures was made available in only two steps from benzene. Our research team that worked this project was diverse, and had many opportunities to engage in outreach at nearby elementary schools. Last Modified: 07/27/2017 Submitted by: Jeffrey S Johnson
